segment.source: Add multiple apps to your enterprise data protection (EDP) Protected Apps list (Windows 10)
segment.target: Add multiple apps to your enterprise data protection (EDP) Protected Apps list (Windows 10)

segment.source: Add multiple apps to your enterprise data protection (EDP) Protected Apps list at the same time, by using the Microsoft Intune Custom URI functionality and the AppLocker.
segment.target: Add multiple apps to your enterprise data protection (EDP) Protected Apps list at the same time, by using the Microsoft Intune Custom URI functionality and the AppLocker.

segment.source: Add multiple apps to your enterprise data protection (EDP) Protected Apps list
segment.target: Add multiple apps to your enterprise data protection (EDP) Protected Apps list

segment.source: Applies to:
segment.target: Applies to:

segment.source: Windows 10 Insider Preview
segment.target: Windows 10 Insider Preview

segment.source: Windows 10 Mobile Preview
segment.target: Windows 10 Mobile Preview

segment.source: [Some information relates to pre-released product, which may be substantially modified before it's commercially released.
segment.target: [Some information relates to pre-released product, which may be substantially modified before it's commercially released.

segment.source: Microsoft makes no warranties, express or implied, with respect to the information provided here.]
segment.target: Microsoft makes no warranties, express or implied, with respect to the information provided here.]

segment.source: Add multiple apps to your enterprise data protection (EDP) Protected Apps list at the same time, by using the Microsoft Intune Custom URI functionality and AppLocker.
segment.target: Add multiple apps to your enterprise data protection (EDP) Protected Apps list at the same time, by using the Microsoft Intune Custom URI functionality and AppLocker.

segment.source: For more info about how to create a custom URI using Intune, see Windows 10 custom policy settings in Microsoft Intune.
segment.target: For more info about how to create a custom URI using Intune, see Windows 10 custom policy settings in Microsoft Intune.

segment.source: Important
segment.target: Important

segment.source: Results can be unpredictable if you configure your policy using both the UI and the Custom URI method together.
segment.target: Results can be unpredictable if you configure your policy using both the UI and the Custom URI method together.

segment.source: We recommend using a single method for each policy.
segment.target: We recommend using a single method for each policy.

segment.source: If you only want to add one app at a time, you can follow the instructions in the Create an enterprise data protection (EDP) policy using Microsoft Intune topic.
segment.target: If you only want to add one app at a time, you can follow the instructions in the Create an enterprise data protection (EDP) policy using Microsoft Intune topic.

segment.source: To add Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps
segment.target: To add Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps

segment.source: Go to the AppLocker UI by opening a command line window and running secpol.msc.
segment.target: Go to the AppLocker UI by opening a command line window and running secpol.msc.

segment.source: The local security policy MMC snap-in opens showing the Security Settings.
segment.target: The local security policy MMC snap-in opens showing the Security Settings.

segment.source: Double-click Application Control Policies, double-click AppLocker, right-click Packaged app Rules, and then click Automatically Generate Rules.
segment.target: Double-click Application Control Policies, double-click AppLocker, right-click Packaged app Rules, and then click Automatically Generate Rules.

segment.source: The Automatically Generate Packaged app Rules wizard opens, letting you create EDP-protected app polices for all of the installed apps on the device or for packaged apps within a specific folder.
segment.target: The Automatically Generate Packaged app Rules wizard opens, letting you create EDP-protected app polices for all of the installed apps on the device or for packaged apps within a specific folder.

segment.source: In the Folder and Permissions screen, keep the default value of Everyone in the User or security group that the rules will apply to box.
segment.target: In the Folder and Permissions screen, keep the default value of Everyone in the User or security group that the rules will apply to box.

segment.source: You want to keep this value because your EDP policy needs to apply to the device being managed, not a single user or group of users.
segment.target: You want to keep this value because your EDP policy needs to apply to the device being managed, not a single user or group of users.

segment.source: Type the name you’ll use to tag the rules into the Name to identify this set of rules box, and then click Next.
segment.target: Type the name you’ll use to tag the rules into the Name to identify this set of rules box, and then click Next.

segment.source: This name should be easily recognizable, such as EDP_UniversalApps_Rules.
segment.target: This name should be easily recognizable, such as EDP_UniversalApps_Rules.

segment.source: In the Rules Preferences screen, keep the default settings, and then click Next to start generating the rules.
segment.target: In the Rules Preferences screen, keep the default settings, and then click Next to start generating the rules.

segment.source: Important
segment.target: Important

segment.source: You can also use Path rules instead of the File hash if you have concerns about unsigned files potentially changing the hash value if they're updated in the future.
segment.target: You can also use Path rules instead of the File hash if you have concerns about unsigned files potentially changing the hash value if they're updated in the future.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: We recommend that you use Publisher rules because they only work with apps you've specifically defined and they can be configured to not require updating simply because a new version came out.
segment.target: We recommend that you use Publisher rules because they only work with apps you've specifically defined and they can be configured to not require updating simply because a new version came out.

segment.source: If you can't use Publisher rules, we then recommend that you use File hash rules.
segment.target: If you can't use Publisher rules, we then recommend that you use File hash rules.

segment.source: File hash rules are a secure alternative that can be used on unsigned code.
segment.target: File hash rules are a secure alternative that can be used on unsigned code.

segment.source: The primary disadvantage to File hash is that every time a binary changes (such as, through servicing updates or upgrades), you'll need to create a new rule.
segment.target: The primary disadvantage to File hash is that every time a binary changes (such as, through servicing updates or upgrades), you'll need to create a new rule.

segment.source: Finally, there's Path rules.
segment.target: Finally, there's Path rules.

segment.source: Path rules are easier to set up and maintain, but can let apps bypass enterprise data protection (EDP) by simply renaming and moving an unallowed file to match one of the apps on the Protected App list.
segment.target: Path rules are easier to set up and maintain, but can let apps bypass enterprise data protection (EDP) by simply renaming and moving an unallowed file to match one of the apps on the Protected App list.

segment.source: For example, if your Path rule says to allow , it becomes possible to rename DisallowedApp.exe to Notepad.exe, move it into the specified path above, and have it suddenly be allowed.
segment.target: For example, if your Path rule says to allow , it becomes possible to rename DisallowedApp.exe to Notepad.exe, move it into the specified path above, and have it suddenly be allowed.

segment.source: In the Review Rules screen, look over your rules to make sure they’re right, and then click Create to add them to your collection of rules.
segment.target: In the Review Rules screen, look over your rules to make sure they’re right, and then click Create to add them to your collection of rules.

segment.source: In the left pane, right-click AppLocker, click Export Policies, go to where you want to save the XML file and type a file name, click Save, and then clear your AppLocker rules.
segment.target: In the left pane, right-click AppLocker, click Export Policies, go to where you want to save the XML file and type a file name, click Save, and then clear your AppLocker rules.

segment.source: Important
segment.target: Important

segment.source: Be aware that what you're saving are the actual AppLocker rules using your local policy.
segment.target: Be aware that what you're saving are the actual AppLocker rules using your local policy.

segment.source: You don't want to apply these rules to your employee devices, you just want to use them to create and export the XML content.
segment.target: You don't want to apply these rules to your employee devices, you just want to use them to create and export the XML content.

segment.source: You must delete the AppLocker rules before you apply your policy.
segment.target: You must delete the AppLocker rules before you apply your policy.

segment.source: Open the Intune administration console, and go to the Policy node, click Add Policy from the Tasks area, go to Windows, click the Custom Configuration (Windows 10 Desktop and Mobile and later) policy, click Create and Deploy a Custom Policy, and then click Create Policy.
segment.target: Open the Intune administration console, and go to the Policy node, click Add Policy from the Tasks area, go to Windows, click the Custom Configuration (Windows 10 Desktop and Mobile and later) policy, click Create and Deploy a Custom Policy, and then click Create Policy.

segment.source: Type a name (required) and an optional description for your policy into the Name and Description boxes.
segment.target: Type a name (required) and an optional description for your policy into the Name and Description boxes.

segment.source: In the Add one or more OMA-URI settings that control functionality on Windows devices box, click Add.
segment.target: In the Add one or more OMA-URI settings that control functionality on Windows devices box, click Add.

segment.source: Type your new Setting Name and Description into the associated boxes, keeping the default Data Type of String.
segment.target: Type your new Setting Name and Description into the associated boxes, keeping the default Data Type of String.

segment.source: In the OMA-URI box, type
segment.target: In the OMA-URI box, type

segment.source: Open File Explorer, go to the location where you saved your new XML file, and open it using an XML editor, such as Notepad.
segment.target: Open File Explorer, go to the location where you saved your new XML file, and open it using an XML editor, such as Notepad.

segment.source: Copy the text that has a Type of Appx, within the RuleCollection tags, and then go back to Intune and paste the text into the Value box of the Add or edit OMA-URI Setting box.
segment.target: Copy the text that has a Type of Appx, within the RuleCollection tags, and then go back to Intune and paste the text into the Value box of the Add or edit OMA-URI Setting box.

segment.source: For example:
segment.target: For example:

segment.source: Click OK to close the Add or edit OMA-URI Setting box, and then click Save Policy.
segment.target: Click OK to close the Add or edit OMA-URI Setting box, and then click Save Policy.

segment.source: After saving the policy, you’ll need to deploy it to your employee’s devices.
segment.target: After saving the policy, you’ll need to deploy it to your employee’s devices.

segment.source: For more info, see the Deploy your enterprise data protection (EDP) policy topic.
segment.target: For more info, see the Deploy your enterprise data protection (EDP) policy topic.

segment.source: To add Classic Windows applications
segment.target: To add Classic Windows applications

segment.source: Go to the AppLocker UI by opening a command line window and running secpol.msc.
segment.target: Go to the AppLocker UI by opening a command line window and running secpol.msc.

segment.source: The local security policy MMC snap-in opens showing the Security Settings.
segment.target: The local security policy MMC snap-in opens showing the Security Settings.

segment.source: Double-click Application Control Policies, double-click AppLocker, right-click Executable Rules, and then click Automatically Generate Rules.
segment.target: Double-click Application Control Policies, double-click AppLocker, right-click Executable Rules, and then click Automatically Generate Rules.

segment.source: The Automatically Generate Executable Rules wizard opens, letting you create EDP-protected app polices by analyzing the files within a specific folder.
segment.target: The Automatically Generate Executable Rules wizard opens, letting you create EDP-protected app polices by analyzing the files within a specific folder.

segment.source: This name should be easily recognizable, such as EDP_ClassicApps_Rules.
segment.target: This name should be easily recognizable, such as EDP_ClassicApps_Rules.
